I've been working with JUnit for about a year now and I never had the
desire to count "asserts". That might be the reason it's not in the
framework. I, for one, hope it does not become part of the framework.
Moreover, I have grave concerns that once JUnit goes truly Open Source, it
will cease to be a lightweight, simple test framework.

Thoughts?

J. B. Rainsberger  <rainsber@...>
Commerce Suite Accelerator: Rule Services, IBM Toronto Lab
8200 Warden Av, Office A3-735 [A3/FNB/8200/MKM]
Markham ON   L6G 1C7
905 413-2501 (969-2501)


"Di Iorio, Matthew (ISS Atlanta)" <mdiiorio@...> on 07/16/2001 18:10:39

Please respond to junit@yahoogroups.com

To:   "'junit@yahoogroups.com'" <junit@yahoogroups.com>
cc:
Subject:  [junit] Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?



We've done the same with our JUnit.  I've heard a few other people on the
list mention modifying JUnit to count asserts.  Is there a good reason that
it isn't part of the framework?  Since a few of us have already done it,
I'm
sure we could make the change pretty easily.

Matt

-----Original Message-----
From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jason.rogers@...]
Sent: Monday, July 16, 2001 10:40 AM
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [junit] How do I implement a test case for a thrown
exception ?


We have modified JUnit to count asserts, because we find that to be
interesting data for metrics.  Therefore, since we are implying that
something went wrong when it was supposed to, we do an assert to add to the
count.

subject: Re: [junit] Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?
